cons: not get any leave for holiday

review_title: wonderful people / difficult to be promoted
pros: wonderful people here who care deeply about the work they do
cons: difficult to be promoted or advance, lack of transparency at times, many Program Assistants are overworked and underpaid and at the time i worked there, no ladder for upward advancement (maybe that has changed)

pros: Really great company culture. My coworkers were all extremely welcoming.

job_title: Program Associate in San Francisco, CA
pros: Good work environment among like-minded peers.
Kind, accepting, and hard working staff

job_title: Anonymous Contractor in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great staff that are impact driven and down to earth.
Organization committed to racial justice and creating a more equitably Bay Area. Run by committed people.
cons: Compensation is lower than at private endowed foundations.

pros: Fellowship helps open doors to opportunities in the philanthropic sector, great day-to-day training and application of philanthropic practices like grantmaking and relationship-building.
cons: Pay is not commensurate to experience or actual work responsibilities, considering sector and cost of living.

pros: Diverse staff and strong commitment to equity
Fantastic retirement options if you are able to stay longer than 5 years for the vesting period (not documented in the HR packet).
cons:
Every couple of months, a staff member will very mysteriously disappear, accompanied by an awkward email from management.

This is probably because certain managers have a long record of mistreating staff, and rather than address the root of the problem, peer managers will turn a blind eye. 

Despite reported and well-known misconduct and bullying, few changes have been implemented. 

For a long time, staff were denied overtime pay. HR had announced after-hours work was "volunteer" time but that it would be taken into consideration positively during the annual review process. This has since been corrected.

Interdepartmental meetings are inefficient and seem to be held to affirm the authority of management team members.

There is poor interdepartmental communication due to budget allocation battles.

Third party studies are only conducted to affirm management team beliefs regarding staff and salary structure.

Inappropriate professional behavior - yelling, tantrums, lashing out - occurs regularly.

There is an incredibly high turnover rate that management is unwilling to examine or address.

The maximum annual raise for a "superior" review (which according to HR almost nobody qualifies for) is 3%.

job_title: Program Assistant in San Francisco, CA
pros: The San Francisco Foundation is a special place to work.  Fred Blackwell has totally transformed the the vision and operations of the organization, building off SFF's DNA of being a huge player in philanthropy and social impact in the Bay Area.  The staff is very diverse and leadership is open to hearing the perspective and experiences of staff at every level.  Historically that hasn't been the case, and a lot of progress has been made in the past few years trying to undo retaliatory and less-than-positive cultural dynamics here.  So some people still carry that memory and experience.  However in my time there, I had a very positive experience, an amazing manager, and felt very supported.  The HR department does a great job of articulating opportunities for professional development, although there is still room for improvement in that area.  They are also extremely open and responsive and really look out for the employees.  I had to leave because of a life change that took me out of the Bay Area, but I would have stayed should that have not happened.  Loved working here!
cons: Like I said, there could be more professional development opportunities, not just for junior staff.  Some people in management could be better managers.  Not that anyone is unpleasant, but how much of a stake you have in decision-making depends on who you report to.  Managers could be better calibrated so that junior staff across the organization have similarly positive and enriching experiences.

pros: Good benefits and pay rate for the work

cons: Sometimes slow which can be frustrating

pros: The mission is great, the CEO very inspiring, a lot of people are very nice and everyone works hard.
cons: There is no real path to progress and some people are very dismissive of all assistants. The hierarchy is just 2 layers in almost all departments: assistants and managers. A lot of people work in silos which has been recognized as a problem and is. It is also very difficult to get suport when there is so much turnover.

review_title: San Francisco Foundation Admin Assistant (Entry Level)
job_title: Program Assistant in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great benefits, and a good organizational culture led by internal and external social justice values and commitment to bettering the Bay area community at large.
cons: New projects / Staff work load and capacity do not always match up. Staff often feel overloaded

job_title: Senior Program Assistant in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great mission, focus, and learning environment. The best co-workers: intelligent, competent, supportive, kind and passionate. So much knowledge and expertise and openess to teaching as well as learning.  Good health benefits, tuition reimbursement and training expense coverage for upper level staff as well as support staff.
cons: As in most cases, cultural and technological change can take a long time, but there's a willingness and I've seen noticeable progress.
